title.value: WorkArena: How Capable are Web Agents at Solving Common Knowledge Work Tasks?
title.justification: The selected title accurately reflects the main subject of the paper, which is an evaluation of web agents' capabilities in completing common knowledge work tasks.
title.quote: W ORK A RENA : H OW C APABLE ARE W EB AGENTS AT S OLVING C OMMON K NOWLEDGE W ORK TASKS ?

extractions.description: The paper explores the capabilities of large language model-based agents in interacting with software via web browsers. It introduces WorkArena, a benchmark of tasks based on the ServiceNow platform, and BrowserGym, an environment for designing and evaluating web agents. The study reveals that while current agents show promise, there is a significant gap towards full task automation, especially between open and closed-source LLMs.

type.justification: The paper reports on experiments and benchmarks evaluating the performance of web agents on specific tasks, which is characteristic of an empirical study.
type.quote: Our empirical evaluation reveals that while current agents show promise on WorkArena, there remains a considerable gap towards achieving full task automation.

name.justification: The paper focuses on large language models and web agents, which are integral parts of NLP.
name.quote: Recent advancements in the fields of large language and vision models have seen the rapid development of UI assistants, particularly web agents acting through a browser.

name.justification: The paper discusses interaction with software via web browsers and user interfaces, aligning with HCI.
name.quote: Graphical User Interfaces (UIs) are the predominant medium through which people interact with software, serving as a crucial gateway to the digital world.

name.justification: The paper's discussion on the capabilities of large language model-based agents falls under Machine Learning.
name.quote: The scope of our experimental contributions is limited to web agents that rely on language models for reasoning.

name.justification: WebGPT is mentioned as an example of agents capable of browsing the web and answering questions.
name.quote: Recent studies include the seminal work of Nakano et al. (2021) that introduces WebGPT, an agent capable of browsing the web and answering questions via information retrieval.

is_contributed.justification: WebGPT was referenced to provide context on existing research, not as a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Recent studies include the seminal work of Nakano et al. (2021) that introduces WebGPT.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not describe executing WebGPT, it is mentioned as part of related work.
is_executed.quote: Recent studies include the seminal work of Nakano et al. (2021) that introduces WebGPT.

is_compared.justification: WebGPT is mentioned for context, not for direct numerical comparison with models discussed in this paper.
is_compared.quote: Recent studies include the seminal work of Nakano et al. (2021) that introduces WebGPT.

referenced_paper_title.value: WebGPT: Browser-assisted question-answering with human feedback
referenced_paper_title.justification: The title from the references section corresponds to the WebGPT model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Recent studies include the seminal work of Nakano et al. (2021) that introduces WebGPT.

name.justification: The dataset MiniWoB is cited as a previous benchmark for web agents, highlighting its relevance to the study.
name.quote: Notable examples are MiniWoB (Shi et al., 2017a; Liu et al., 2018), which offer a collection of 125 toy web tasks.

referenced_paper_title.value: World of Bits: An open-domain platform for web-based agents
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference for MiniWoB corresponds to Shi et al., 2017a which is about World of Bits.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Notable examples are MiniWoB (Shi et al., 2017a; Liu et al., 2018), which offer a collection of 125 toy web tasks.

name.justification: WebArena is mentioned as a challenging benchmark used in the study for evaluating web agents.
name.quote: More recently, Zhou et al. (2023) introduced WebArena, a collection of 190 tasks based on realistic websites.

referenced_paper_title.value: WebArena: A realistic web environment for building autonomous agents
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference from Zhou et al. (2023) aligns with the WebArena benchmark discussed in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: More recently, Zhou et al. (2023) introduced WebArena, a collection of 190 tasks based on realistic websites.

name.justification: Playwright is mentioned as a tool used for browser automation in the paper.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Playwright is discussed in the context of automating browser tasks, aligning with its documentation.
